author: michaelrycroft
content:
Apologies for the really long post but I had a thought today and wondered was there any reason why this was never implemented.
It was a thought around the whole ‚Äúyour private key, your cryptocurrency‚Äù debate, as it stands all cryptocurrencies in your wallet are protected only via a private key/mnemonic phrase but nothing really binds the individual coins to you, the only safeguard and protection is the private key, lose this and you lose everything.
Comparable historically to a problem with cash money which would arise if you lost it or it was stolen from you, it can be used by another person/entity with no challenge to its ownership and no authorization needed to use it.
This was somewhat mitigated with the advent of credit/debit cards which required a signature or pin to authorize payments, although card theft and unauthorized usage is still prevalent, this provided some protection to consumers by limiting the theft to a certain number of individuals with a particular skill set. 
Although the very same problem still exists today, if your money is stolen it will more often than not disappear into anonymity and lost forever.
With that rather long preface out of the way.

author: michaelrycroft
content:
With the advancement of digital currencies wouldn‚Äôt a solution to this problem be achieved by having the coins themselves individually tied to an ‚Äòidentifier‚Äô right down to the lowest denomination? Wei in Ethereum. 
Instead of having a wallet full of currency that has no direct association with the owner, the coins in your wallet would have your own ‚Äòidentifier‚Äô embedded, this would be akin to writing your own name on every banknote and coin in your wallet, if you transfer or spend coins then they would then be re-identified to the seller/person‚Äôs ‚Äòidentifier‚Äô.
Only you can authorize the re-identification of ownership in any transaction thus making any theft pointless due to the coin needing the correct identification for future trades, this would have parallels to stealing a cell phone that incorporates a very strong password which hopefully the thief cannot break into and which renders the item a valueless ornament. 
Wouldn‚Äôt this also allow for a more trusted trade? You can send coins but only when re-identification is complete would the coins ‚Äòidentifier‚Äô ownership be changed and no longer yours.
The same with exchanges or schemes where cryptocurrencies are pooled, the coins would be available to trade but still tied to you through your ‚Äòidentifier‚Äô, this would surely prevent large scale theft by unscrupulous businesses because the only real outcome would be a wallet full of unusable coins.
Are there any glaringly obvious reasons why this couldn‚Äôt work?
